choices.D: Clear the OSPF process on R1 to flush stale LSAs sent by other routers.
choices.B: Increase the SPF delay interval on R1 to synchronize routes.
choices.A: Disconnect the router with the OSPF router ID 0.0.0 0 from the network.
choices.C: Change the R1 router ID from 10.255.255.1 to a unique value and clear the process.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. After configuring OSPF in R1, some external destinations in the network became unreachable. Which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The OSPF Router ID 10.255.255.1 is not unique, thus "OSPF-4-FLOOD_WAR" error message is generated on the affected routers.
R1 is one of the affected devices, so "C) Change the R1 router ID from 10.255.255.1 to a unique value and clear the process" resolves the issue.

comments.content:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/open-shortest-path-first-ospf/118880-technote-ospf-00.html
OSPF-4-FLOOD_WAR
"...Type-5 LSAs when there is a duplicate router ID in different OSPF Areas"

https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/ospf-4-flood-war-messages-after-config-change/td-p/2506500
"For OSPF to function correctly the IP addresses of transit networks must be unique. 
If it is not unique the conflicting routers reports this error message. 
In the error message the router with the OSPF router ID reported as adv-rtr reports this message."

"show ip ospf database self-originate" displays LSAs from the local router = R1. 
R1 has the OSPF Router ID 10.255.255.1 (displayed as "adv-rtr" or "ADV Router").
As we see, R1 originates a type 5 LSA with a link ID of 0.0.0.0, which is the default route (from default-information originate).
That is where the router ID conflict occurs.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is corerct

C correct answer
Ref: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/open-shortest-path-first-ospf/9237-9.html

choices.A: Configure the Spoke 2 users IP on the router B OSPF domain
choices.D: Configure encapsulation dot1q 78 on the router C interface
choices.B: Configure IPv6 on the routers B and C interfaces
choices.C: Configure OSPFv2 on the routers B and C interfaces

discussion.content: Fucking idiotic question. It tests nothing in terms of knowledge. How do you apply for the job of making questions for Cisco exams, seems like an easy jobâ€¦

comments.content: In OSPFv3 we need a link-local ipv6 address to run ospfv3 ipv4 or ospfv3 ipv6 over the ipv6 link-local address. In cisco routers we configure link-local address manually or use ipv6 enable we get a link-lical in form of fe80::/10 with a modification of the mac-address.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
using ospf v3 you need IPV6 enable

Selected Answer: B
B is corerct 

because of ospf v3

I agree that this question is somewhat stupid, the interface will not even take the ospfv3 configuration command unless ipv6 is already enabled on the interface, not sure how they managed to display and interface config with the ospfv3 command already in place without the ipv6 enable 

ABR0-1(config-if)#ospfv3 1 ipv4 area 0
% OSPFv3: IPV6 is not enabled on this interface
ABR0-1(config-if)#ipv6 enable
ABR0-1(config-if)#ospfv3 1 ipv4 area 0
ABR0-1(config-if)#^Z
That is the most bizarre and stupid question I have ever read.
None of these answers would really fix the problem. Who writes these question! Absolutely terrible.

comments.content: If it's this dumps are really valid, im really dissapointed with cisco, like the 90% of the questions at this question are horrible

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer "B". abd123 is right, "ipv6 enable" is missing for ospfv3.

My guesses:
The connecting routers should have one leg in OSPF area 0. Certainly, the interfaces for connection B-C should be in OSPF area 0, and that is missing on Router B.
All interfaces in IPv6 OSPFv3 domain should have an IPv6 address, and that is missing on Router C. 
For me it looks like a frame relay topology, so probably the encapsulation should be frame relay.
So many problems to see here! Area-Mismatch, maybe an encapsulation mismatch and yes also IPv6 is also an problem here. But none of the answers make sense in this case!

Agree with ChillingAgain 
can someone explain this question?
Badly written question? Cannot understand what would be a valid option. Any ideas, someone?

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer receives a report that Spoke 1 users can perform bank transactions with the server located at the Center site, but Spoke 2 users cannot. Which action resolves the issue?
What is an MPLS LDP targeted session?

choices.A: LDP session established by exchanging multicast hello packets
choices.B: LDP session established between LSRs by exchanging TCP hello packets
choices.C: session between neighbors that are connected no more than one hop away
choices.D: label distribution session between non-directly connected neighbors

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is corerct

Selected Answer: D
Given answer is correct.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/mpls/targeted-ldp-sessions/td-p/2288569

choices.C: There is no spoke-to-spoke connection. DMVPN configuration should be modified to enable a tunnel connection between R2 and R3 and neighbor relationship confirmed by use of the show ip eigrp neighbor command.
choices.B: There is no spoke-to-spoke connection. DMVPN configuration should be modified with a manual neighbor relationship configured between R2 and R3 and confirmed by use of the show ip eigrp neighbor command.
choices.A: Split horizon prevents the routes from being advertised between spoke routers. It should be disabled with the no ip split-horizon eigrp 10 command on the Gi0/0 interface of R1.
choices.D: Split horizon prevents the routes from being advertised between spoke routers. It should be disabled with the command no ip split-horizon eigrp 10 on the tunnel interface of R1.

Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configures DMVPN and receives the hub location prefix of 10.1.1.0/24 on R2 and R3. The R3 prefix of 10.1.3.0/24 is not received on R2, and the R2 prefix 10.1.2.0/24 is not received on R3. Which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content: Answer D is correct: https://networkdirection.net/articles/routingandswitching/dmvpn/dmvpn-and-dynamic-routing/

Selected Answer: D
D is corerct

Selected Answer: D
D correct

Given answer in correct


.

DHCP servers have a UDP port number of 67
DHCP clients have the UDP port number 68

Selected Answer: AE
Given answer is correct per cisco book page 58.
DHCP Message Description
DHCPDISCOVER A client sends this message in an attempt to locate a DHCP server. 
This message is sent to broadcast IP address 255.255.255.255, using 
UDP port 67.
DHCPOFFER A DHCP server sends this message in response to a 
DHCPDISCOVER message, using UDP port 68.

Selected Answer: AE
A & E are corerct

comments.content: 67 is for servers, but clients do listen on 68, so we need both

discussion.content: another amazing quesitons, we only need 67..but it asks for 2 so hey!

comments.content: you're right. The Client listens on 68 for the offer and ack parts of DORA, and because this ACL is inbound, port 68 should not matter as a destination port, it would matter as a source port.

discussion.content: Don't see why we need two answers, WE only need port 67 for server access.

choices.E: Configure access-list 100 permit udp any any eq 67 as the first line
choices.D: Configure access-list 100 permit udp any any eq 66 as the first line
choices.B: Configure access-list 100 permit udp any any eq 69 as the first line
choices.A: Configure access-list 100 permit udp any any eq 68 as the first line
choices.C: Configure access-list 100 permit udp any any eq 61 as the first line
